content:
AUSTRALIA

Bank of Queensland (BOQ AT) - ASIC has commenced proceedings against the Co. for unfair contract terms, while the Co. has begun review of all small business lending contracts since November 2016 and will compensate any small business customers it finds were adversely affected. (Newswires)

Cleanaway Waste Management (CWY AT) - Co. is seen as front runner to acquire SKM Recycling. (Newswires)

Oil Search (OSH AT) - Papua New Guinea agrees to allowed the LNG gas project to proceed and Total (FP FP) agreed to certain concessions including allowing 3rd party access to the petroleum pipeline. (Newswires)

SpeedCast International (SDA AT) - Lenders are thought to be seeking to acquire AUD 893mln of SpeedCast’s term B debt. (Newswires)

Suncorp-Metway (SUN AT) - Co. considering various options for ACM Parts business. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Fast Retailing (9983 JT) - Co. August domestic same store sales rose 9.9% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Recruit Holdings (6098 JT) - Japan’s Labour Ministry is to warn Co. unit regarding data sales. (Newswires)

Sony (6758 JT) - Co. announced plans for next generation NUCLeUS smart imaging platform for healthcare industry. (Newswires)

United Arrows (7606 HK) - Co. August same store sales rose 12.2% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Other News - Japanese PM Abe is planning to keep Nakai as LDP Secretary General. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Asiana Airlines (020560 KS) - Aekyung and 2 consortiums submitted preliminary bids for the Co. (Yonhap)

Nongshim (004370 KS) - Co. will invest USD 200mln to build a 2nd US factory. (Yonhap)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) - Co. has begun to substitute materials from Japan with local supplies in its chip production process. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump reiterated the US is doing very well with China negotiations and that China will get a tougher deal if he wins 2020 elections, while he added that in the meantime, China’s supply chain will crumble and businesses, jobs and money will be gone. In related news, US President Trump was reportedly so angered by China's latest tariff retaliation that he wanted to double the tariffs but resorted to a 5% hike after speaking with CEO's, according to three sources cited by CNBC. (Twitter/CNBC)

Chinese Vice Premier Liu He said China firmly opposes trade war, while he hopes the two sides seek common ground while setting aside differences and appropriately resolve the issues on basis of equality as well as mutual respect. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin said he cannot tell whether US President Trump is threatening China or pleading with China to make concessions and that China always wants to reach a deal but will always reject bullying demands. (Twitter)

New Zealand GDT Price Index -0.4% (Prev. -0.2%) and Whole Milk Powder Index -0.8% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK Parliament voted to approve motion to seize control of Parliamentary time to try and block a no deal as expected with the motion passed by 328 votes in favour vs. 301 against. The vote occurred after UK Parliament Speaker Bercow granted lawmakers an emergency debate, while reports later noted the Tory party are set to break convention and will stand against Speaker Bercow in the next general election. Furthermore, UK government sources confirmed 21 rebels will be kicked out of the party for voting against the government. (Newswires/Telegraph)

UK PM Johnson reiterated he believes he will get a deal with Brussels and that the UK will leave on October 31st without a deal if needed, while he added an election will be the only way to resolve this if lawmakers vote for Brexit delay. Of note, there were earlier reports that UK PM Johnson answered the government will uphold the constitution and obey the law when asked what he would do if bill passes that rules out a No-Deal Brexit. (Newswires)

UK Opposition Labour Leader Corbyn said the meeting with opposition leaders went very well and they are working to block a no-deal, while he is confident that we can have a general election and prevent a no-deal Brexit from occurring but later suggested they will not vote for a general election before extension to leaving the EU. (Newswires)

Conservative MP Philip Lee defected to the Lib Dems and therefore the Conservatives no longer have a majority in the House of Commons, according to ITV's Brand. In related news, an EU Diplomat said now that UK PM Johnson has lost his majority it is futile to continue discussions and that we cannot be sure that whatever were to come out of it will ever be translated into reality. (Twitter)

EU Member states have been told by the EU commission task force that the UK is reneging on its commitments to protect the all-Ireland economy, according to RTE’s Tony Connely. (Twitter)

ECB Policymakers are said to be leaning towards a rate cut and tiering, as well as reinforced guidance in September 12th stimulus package, according sources. Many also support QE but opposition from some northern states complicates the discussion and the ECB is said to have room for around 1yr of QE using flexibility under existing rules with no immediate need to change issuer limit. Furthermore, the new guidance will emphasize conditions needed for a rate lift-off and de-emphasize date component although the sources added that the discussion about ECB stimulus package is open, ongoing and no decision has been made, while it is also seen as vital for the ECB to leave some tools unused for incoming ECB President Lagarde. (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy said it is clear monetary policy needs to maintain its full support and be ready to strengthen it, while he added that ECB has option of re-starting APP at any time but questioned if now is the right time and noted the priority today is to better anchor inflation expectations to our target which should be tackled by reinforced guidance. (Newswires)

ECB’s Muller reiterated there is no strong case to resume bond buying and that market expectations on stimulus have gone too far, while he is going into next week’s meeting with an open mind but thinks a rate cut should be the first option if action is needed. (Newswires)

Italian 5SM members back the formation of new government with PD following online vote (79.3% in favour, compared to polls forecasting 51%). (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Cons PMI (Aug) 45.0 vs. Exp. 45.5 (Prev. 45.3). (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif said new cuts in Iranians commitments to the nuclear deal does not mean the "end of talks", while there were also comments from an Iranian official that Iran is able to resume production of 20% enriched uranium in 2 days. (Newswires/ISNA)

US Treasury Department issued fresh Iran-related sanctions on the Iran Space Agency and Iran Space Center & Astronautics Research Institute. (Newswires)

French diplomatic source stated an additional violation of the nuclear deal by Iran would send the "wrong signal", but the need to find a solution would remain. (Newswires) 

 

US

Fed's Bullard (Voter, Dovish) said a 50bps cut would align the Fed with market expectations and that the policy rate is too high, while he suggested it is better to get to the right point now rather than in small steps and that aggressive action is needed given the fall in yields as well as trade impact. (Newswires)

US President Trump criticized the Fed again in which he stated that Germany and other countries have negative rates and the Federal Reserve fails to act, while he also noted that Germany are the US's 'weak currency competitors'. Furthermore, US President Trump criticised both EU & China on trade in which he suggested both treat the US very unfairly on trade. (Twitter)

US Chamber of Commerce’s Donohue said he thinks if the USMCA deal is passed, it would send a positive signal to China and that he believes congress has enough votes to pass the USMCA deal right now. (Newswires)

NHC said a tropical cyclone is expected to form later today over south west Gulf of Mexico and tropical storm warnings have been issued for portions of north east Mexico. (Newswires)

  • US Markit Manufacturing PMI Final (Aug) 50.3 (Prev. 49.9). (Newswires)
  • US ISM Manufacturing PMI Aug 49.1 vs. Exp. 51.1 (Prev. 51.2) 

 

MARKET RECAP

US stock markets declined with sentiment weighed by ongoing US-China trade uncertainty as well as weak data in which US ISM Manufacturing fell into contraction for the first time since 2016. In stocks specific, Amazon (AMZN) outperformed today following a PT rise to USD 2600 from USD 2250 at RBC as they forecast shares to rise nearly 50% on the roll out of US one-day Prime delivery. Boeing (BA) was lower amid further delays to its 777 MAX planes as American Airlines (AAL) also announce a delay to their expected return of the jet, joining United Airlines (UAL) who do not see it ungrounding until December. Apple Insider reported Apple (AAPL) iPhone production is at similar levels of production to the prior year, AAPL traded lower by ~2% for most of the session. American Tower Corp (AMT) also traded higher after it was announced it is entering a new partnership with AT&T (T).  The energy sector tracked oil prices throughout the session which weighed on Concho Resources (CXO), who initially traded higher in the pre-market as it is to sell its Mexico Shelf assets for USD 925mln and is to initiate a USD 1.5bln share repurchase programme. Casino Names (WYNN, LVS, MLCO, MGM) were hit as August’s Macau Casino revenue missed expectations where it fell 8.6%, missing estimates for a 4% fall. Semiconductors were mixed, KLA Tencor (KLAC) and Lam Research (LRCX) were higher after upgrades at Evercore, however other names Xilinx (XLNX), Micron (MU) & Western Digital (WDC) were lower. Elsewhere in the semiconductor space, Samsung has started replacing Japanese materials with local suppliers for its production of semiconductors, a move which could offset Japan’s restrictions on high-tech exports to South Korea. CBS (CBS) & Viacom (VIAB) were lower after brokerages cut both names’ PT on the deal between the two. S&P 500 -0.7% AT 2906, NASDAQ-100 -1.1% AT 7610, DOW JONES -1.1% AT 26118.

The TPLEX bull steepened as a tumbling-into-contraction US ISM Manufacturing PMI raised the chances of Fed easing at its September meeting. The ISM figure surprised the market after falling into contraction (49.1), the first time since 2016, swiftly seeing Treasuries leg higher. However, prices since came off their highs, likely a function of the large slate of corporate issuance – 21 IG deals – but desks noted a large chunk of said issuance is expected to swap, providing a limit to the fade. At settlement the curve was generally steeper with the 2s30s widening by over 3bps, although the 5-year yield fell by just under 4.5bps which was slightly more than the 2-year yield’s decline. US T-note (U9) futures settled 13 ticks higher at 132-04.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 3rd September 2019: ISM Manufacturing falls into contraction putting fresh pressure on Fed
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 3rd September 2019: ISM Manufacturing falls into contraction putting fresh pressure on Fed

* SNAPSHOT: Equities lower, Treasuries higher, Dollar flat, Crude lower.

* REAR VIEW: US ISM mfg. falls into contraction; China cautious on trade concessions; UK lawmakers set to pass No-Deal block; ECB sources indicate a rate cut, tiering, and reinforced forward guidance; 5SM approve PD coalition

* COMING UP: Data: Australian GDP, Chinese Caixin Services PMI, EZ & UK Composite & Services PMI, EZ Retail Sales, US International Trade, ISM-New York Index, Canadian Trade Balance Event: Fed's Beige Book, BoE Treasury Select Committee Hearing Speakers: Fed's Williams, Kaplan, Bullard, Bowman, Kashkari & Evans, ECB's Lane, Mersch & de Guindos

 

* US AUGUST ISM MANUFACTURING: The ISM manufacturing survey fell into contractionary territory in August (49.1 against an expected 51.2 from a prior 51.3) – the first time since February 2016 – and is contrary to the signal from regional Fed manufacturing surveys, as well as Markit’s manufacturing PMI for August, which improved on July levels; however, ISM have often noted that any reading above 42.9 generally indicates an expansion of the overall economy. It is hard to put a positive spin on the data. Pantheon Macroeconomics says the story is about the China slowdown and the trade war, with the latter now the biggest issue, judging from the widening gap between the ISM new orders component, and the China’s Caixin manufacturing PMI report, which has risen a couple of points from the January low. At the same time, Pantheon points out, export orders have dropped to the lowest since April 2009 (post Lehman crash), and the employment sub index has fallen to a three-year low at 47.4, from 51.7. “In short, we can find no good news here,” Pantheon writes, "the survey is not yet consistent with a steep downturn in the broader economy – manufacturing already has been contracting for two quarters – but another couple of months of declines on this scale would leave the US facing an entirely unnecessary and self-inflicted recession."

* US/CHINA: China state news overnight reported that giving the US any trade concessions would be a "grave error," and that Chinese officials are in no rush to secure a deal, casting into doubt President Trump's assertions that China wants to make a deal, and that trade talks are progressing. Chinese Vice Premier Liu He said China firmly opposes a trade war, hopes the two sides seek common ground while setting aside differences, and he hopes to appropriately resolve the issues on basis of equality and mutual respect. However, China state news Xinhua also suggested that Liu He's comments follow a meeting with a delegation led by US Senator Steve Daines, and Agricultural Secretary Perdue in China on Tuesday. Note, Daines, is also co-chair of the U.S. House of Senate US-China Working Group. Both US representatives said they are not willing to see economic and trade conflicts between the two sides.

* BOC PREVIEW: BoC Policy announcement due Wednesday 4th September at 1500BST/1000EDT. The Bank is expected to keep rates unchanged at 1.75%. It is a statement-only meeting; no post-meeting press conference with Governor Poloz, and no updated economic projections. However, BoC Deputy Governor Schembri will deliver his Economic Progress Report on Thursday. While the Street does not expect any policy action in September, it will be keeping an eye out for clues on what the central bank will do in October. To download the report, please click here.

* BREXIT: The vote results of the No-Deal motion is expected to be released no later than 22.30BST/17.30ET, with rumours likely to be released before-hand. The government is expected to lose given the 16 tory rebels fails to provide PM Johnson a majority, which means that UK lawmakers will take control of parliament on Wednesday and push through legislation to delay Brexit until January 2020; but before the lawmakers can legislate, however, PM Johnson has intimated he'd call general elections. If UK PM Johnson does win it would leave him scope for him to force Brexit, with or without a deal on the 31st October. Elsewhere, Brexit Secretary Barclay has called on the EU to be "creative and flexible" in finding solutions to the Irish border issue, though did not provide any details on a solution. Meanwhile, on the domestic front, UK construction PMI showed the sector's downturn is intensifying, BRC data showed UK retail sales flatlining in August, while Barclaycard data showed consumer spending rising by 1.3% in August (it grew by 4.5% in August 2018). Click here for further analysis on tonight’s vote.

* ECB: Sources reported that ECB policymakers are leaning towards a rate cut and tiering (both go hand in hand, the report implied), as well as reinforced forward guidance as part of a stimulus package at its 12th September meeting. Many are also supportive of QE, but opposition from some northern states is complicating discussions. The report said the central bank has room for around one year of QE, using flexibility under existing rules, and there would unlikely be any tweaks to its issuer limits. The new guidance will emphasise conditions needed for rate lift-off, and de-emphasise the calendar elements of forward guidance, the report said. Elsewhere, the article noted that discussions were open and ongoing, and no final decision had been made. Finally, the piece noted that there was no reason to stagger the stimulus package over several meetings, while there is a line of thought that the central bank also wants to leave some tools unused for incoming ECB President Lagarde, who is due to take the role from the outgoing Draghi in November. Elsewhere, ECB's Villeroy said that monetary policy needs to maintain its full support and be ready to strengthen it; ECB has option of re-starting APP at any time but questioned if now is the right time (which could be viewed as more “hawkish”). The Bank of France Governor added that APP will remain an essential instrument of monetary policy, the priority today is to better anchor inflation expectations to our target, which should be tackled by reinforced guidance.

* ITALY: The 5SM party members voted 79.3% in favour of the formation of a new government with the PD party, well exceeding previous poll estimates of 51% in favour. PM Conte will now see Italian President Mattarella on Wednesday morning to formally announce he is ready to form a new government.

* SPAIN: Spain’s PSOE has made proposals aimed at winning the support of Podemos, in order to form a Socialist government. However, sources who are reportedly familiar with the thinking of acting PM Sanchez, and PSOE chief, said the Socialists now see a repeat election as the more likely outcome. Sanchez has recently stated that there were too many disagreements to form a government with the far left Podemos, but he did offer an option that would see parties agree on policies, and give non-cabinet positions to Podemos; Podemos’ chief Iglesias rejected this, stating a coalition government is the only option. If there is no deal on a government by the 23rd September, elections will be held on November 10th

* IRAN: French Foreign Minister said that discussions with Iran focused on setting up credit lines guaranteed by oil are ongoing, but in return Iran needs to comply fully to the Nuclear Deal; he caveated that the credit line plan depends on the US reissuing oil export waivers, something of a hurdle given that Washington and Tehran are not even talking currently. As the Iran-set deadline of September 5th for the EU to salvage the Nuclear Deal approaches, Iran reiterated that it is prepared to make a third deviation from its commitments if the deadline is not met. A French diplomatic source said an additional violation of the nuclear deal by Iran would send the "wrong signal", but the need to find a solution would remain.

* WTI (V9) SETTLED USD 1.16 LOWER AT USD 53.94/BBL; BRENT (X9) SETTLED USD 0.40 LOWER AT USD 58.26/BBL: Crude prices moved decisively lower through the day amid US-China sentiment souring and a tumble in US ISM Manufacturing PMIs, although did find support at the tail-end of the US session. The losses were led by WTI, which suffered more than Brent, with hurricane Dorian also likely playing its part, but several technical support levels were broken throughout the day in both benchmarks. Some desks have also been attributing weakness to OPEC+ survey data which has been showing slight increases from producers, although Citi’s analyst highlight that the increases were mainly from Nigeria and Iraq, “never the stalwarts of OPEC compliance,” with the pinnacle Saudi output remaining within production limits, alluding to the natural volatility of the data rather than an active deviation from output curbs. API and EIA US energy inventories are both delayed by 24 hours due to US Labor Day on Monday.

* US T-NOTE (U9) FUTURES SETTLED 13 TICKS HIGHER AT 132-04. The TPLEX bull steepened as a tumbling-into-contraction US ISM Manufacturing PMI raised the chances of Fed easing at its September meeting. The ISM figure surprised the market after falling into contraction (49.1), the first time since 2016, swiftly seeing Treasuries leg higher. However, prices since came off their highs, likely a function of the large slate of corporate issuance – 21 IG deals – but desks noted a large chunk of said issuance is expected to swap, providing a limit to the fade. At settlement the curve was generally steeper with the 2s30s widening by over 3bps, although the 5-year yield fell by just under 4.5bps which was slightly more than the 2-year yield’s decline.

* S&P 500 -0.7% AT 2906, NASDAQ-100 -1.1% AT 7610, DOW JONES -1.1% AT 26118, S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  -0.4%, Consumer Staples  0.5%, Energy  -0.6%, Financials  -1.1%, Health Care  -0.6%, Industrials  -1.4%, Information Technology  -1.3%, Materials  -0.9%, Telecommunication Services  -1%, Utilities  1.8%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Amazon (AMZN) outperformed today following a PT rise to USD 2600 from USD 2250 at RBC as they forecast shares to rise nearly 50% on the roll out of US one-day Prime delivery. Boeing (BA) was lower amid further delays to its 777 MAX planes as American Airlines (AAL) also announce a delay to their expected return of the jet, joining United Airlines (UAL) who do not see it ungrounding until December. Apple Insider reported Apple (AAPL) iPhone production is at similar levels of production to the prior year, AAPL traded lower by ~2% for most of the session. American Tower Corp (AMT) also traded higher after it was announced it is entering a new partnership with AT&T (T).  The energy sector tracked oil prices throughout the session which weighed on Concho Resources (CXO), who initially traded higher in the pre-market as it is to sell its Mexico Shelf assets for USD 925mln and is to initiate a USD 1.5bln share repurchase programme. Casino Names (WYNN, LVS, MLCO, MGM) were hit as August’s Macau Casino revenue missed expectations where it fell 8.6%, missing estimates for a 4% fall. Semiconductors were mixed, KLA Tencor (KLAC) and Lam Research (LRCX) were higher after upgrades at Evercore, however other names Xilinx (XLNX), Micron (MU) & Western Digital (WDC) were lower. Elsewhere in the semiconductor space, Samsung has started replacing Japanese materials with local suppliers for its production of semiconductors, a move which could offset Japan’s restrictions on high-tech exports to South Korea. CBS (CBS) & Viacom (VIAB) were lower after brokerages cut both names’ PT on the deal between the two.

* RBA: Left rates unchanged at 1.0%, as was expected. The central bank maintained guidance that "it will will continue to monitor developments, including in the labour market, and ease monetary policy further if needed to support sustainable growth in the economy and the achievement of the inflation target over time" - crucially, it left in the phrase "if needed" which leaves it with some optionality with regards to an October move; some had argued that removing the phrase would have been a more explicit signal of a coming rate cut. There were some other tweaks that received attention: there was a more forceful noting of the weakening global capex cycle; the RBA also removed language about the jobless rate falling to around 5.0% in a couple of years, which was part expected after the recent SOMP saw the central bank's unemployment rate forecast inch higher. Additionally, the final paragraph was tweaked in a way that suggests that, while the labour market is important, it does not seem to be a key driver of policy; the Board will now "continue to monitor developments, including the labour market," whereas previously, it was continuing "to monitor developments in the labour market closely" - RBC's analysts said that amid some mixed domestic data, this sentence suggests that the high frequency policy-sensitive data is more important for policy deliberations, and the bank suggests that given that the RBA has made it clear that it expects its policy action and fiscal stimulus to lend some support to households in the coming months, there is some uncertainty about its potential impact. Looking ahead, RBC thinks a clearer picture will emerge later this year. "The soft data – confidence, business surveys, auction clearance rates as greater volume comes on stream – and the hard data – housing finance approvals, retail sales, motor vehicle purchases – are likely to be top of the RBA’s watching list in the coming months," the bank writes, "the very early signs are mixed which suggests that the RBA will likely sit on the side-lines for a bit longer awaiting a clearer picture unless forced to act by global developments." In wake of the decision, money markets price the probability of a 25bps October rate cut with around 60% certainty, little changed compared with before the decision.

* FX WRAP: USD, CNY: The Dollar Index rose above 99.00 overnight, as US/China trade uncertainties return, while some had also attributed GBP's downside (which is dragging EUR with it) as a support for the buck in early trade too; but the buck went negative after a grim ISM report. Nevertheless, Morgan Stanley says the buck is making it more difficult for Chinese authorities to stabilise the yuan. The bank argues that China fixing the RMB stronger than model expectations suggests that authorities may have no interest in a volatility spike ahead of the 70th anniversary of the People's Republic of China (PRC) on 1st October, explaining that yuan stability often acted as a shock absorber, but with global economic weakness becoming increasingly visible, it will be the stronger USD transmitting global economic weakness into the US, which MS says supports its view that USD strength and strong US risk appetite may not co-exist for long. "Investors may soon learn that the stronger yuan fixing may not prevent US equity markets from falling," and "what matters for US risk markets is the US growth outlook and its impact on US corporate profitability, and there, the combination of USD strength and global demand weakness do not bode well."

GBP: Technicians say that now GBPUSD 1.20 has been given, the door is open to a move lower to 1.15. The folks at ING have introduced a new sterling risk premium tracker, which looks at various measures of sterling stress, gauged by factors like its own short-term financial fair value models, as well as speculative length. The bank says its model signals the risk of no deal Brexit/early election is underpriced by the market, and is looking for more downside to GBP. That theme is certainly in line with other analysts, who have suggested that there is little in the way of positive scenarios for GBP currently, and now 1.20 has been cracked, the post referendum low between 1.1830-40 comes into immediate view. However, with Brexit, the situation is always fluid, and any ground rebel MPs make could engineer aggressive sterling upside, given that positioning remains short; however, many would view GBP rallies as an opportunity to sell back into higher levels. Throughout the session GBPUSD drifted higher towards 1.21 amid ongoing Brexit developments as the opposition pushed to delay Brexit by 3 months in a bill which is expected to pass, a defeat for the government. However, Johnson will look to either call a snap election or delay the motion coming into law if it is passed.

EUR: The EUR is under pressure from GBP woes, but also traders focussing attention on next week's ECB. This week's manufacturing PMIs continued to signal the challenges within the Eurozone, and the market is expecting a package of easing from the ECB next week (also seen in today's Bund trading, where yields fell to fresh lows around -74bps). UBS notes that bounces in EURUSD have been very shallow since the break below 1.10 last week, and says that in the last couple of days, it has seen increased downside interest in cash and options from clients, and accordingly, the bank says it still prefers to sell EUR on rallies to the 1.0960-70 region.

AUD: Money market pricing of RBA rate cuts is little changed after the central bank stood pat overnight, and instead, the AUD received some support from a surprise current account surplus, auguring well for Wednesday's Q2 GDP release (analysts see a 0.6% increase from net exports). SocGen argues that, in theory, the surplus supports a higher AUD valuation, but in the case of Australia this is pretty meaningless in the short-term given the central bank is trying to counter trade war headwinds with lower interest rates

CAD: The risk sensitive currency saw downside amid falling oil prices printing lows of 1.3323, just above the 200dma of 1.3312. USDCAD then pared back gains following a weaker dollar after disappointing PMI data in the states.

TRY: Turkish inflation cooled by more than expected in August (15.0% Y/Y vs previous 16.7%), and was broad-based, which analysts say leaves the door open for the CBRT to cut rates aggressively at its meeting next week. Capital Economics is expecting a 250bps rate cut next week to  17.25% (NOTE: 300bps is priced), and its analysts say that with inflation likely to dip into single digits in September and October, more easing lies in store; it sees rates being cut to 16.00% by early next year, but warns that risks lie to the downside. However, looking further ahead, CapEco says that inflation is likely to rise again, and the TRY is likely to come under pressure, forcing the MPC to reverse course.

ZAR: GDP data surprised to the upside, in a sign the country might avoid recession this year, though the ZAR moves were limited after the knee jerk reaction. Ahead of the data, the argument was that a weak print would strengthen the SARB's case to loosen policy. Nevertheless, the Street still feels that the better than expected growth does little to stop credit rating downgrades linked to debt issues including bailouts for state power utility, Eskom.

SEK: Ahead of Thursday's Riksbank rate decision, SEB notes there is a discrepancy between market pricing and its own investor survey. The bank says strong expectations of a rate cut suggest that the Riksbank is unlikely to surprise already very dovish sentiment, and it thinks the risk reward is to be long SEK over the Riksbank. Its own investor survey finds participants are still positioned for lower rates, but have scaled down positions for a flatter curve, and the bank says it sticks with its view that the 2s5s rate trades to flat given Riksbank’s limited possibility to cut the rate much further.

subject: PRIMER: Tonight's Brexit vote
content:
Timings: 

  • Until 10pm The emergency debate will take place.
  • No later than 10pm - The MPs will vote on the deal with the result to be announced by 10.30pm BST

ANALYSIS

  • Tonight's vote is a de facto confidence motion on the government of PM Johnson. If the government loses, as seems to be the base case among analysts, UK lawmakers will take control of parliament on Wednesday, and push through legislation to delay Brexit until January 2020; but before the lawmakers can legislate, however, PM Johnson has intimated he'd call general elections. If the government wins (the liklihood of which is diminishing), it would strengthen Johnson's hand, leaving scope for him to force a Brexit -- with or without an exit deal -- on 31st October. A vote on whether elections can take place would likely occur on Wednesday.
  • The odds of an election went up today, even before the lawmakers' vote, after Philip Lee defected to the Liberal Democrats, leaving Johnson's government without a working majority. There has previously been suggestions that an election could be held on 14th October, ahead of the European Council summit on 17-18th October.
  • Recent polling implies the Conservatives would win a majority, Capital Economics observes, noting that the Conservatives have jumped from 21% to 32% in the polls since Johnson became PM, and Electoral Calculus' prediction of the election result based on those polls is even more favourable – predicting a Conservative majority of 62. "Much would depend on Brexit policies and pacts, as essentially it would be an election on Brexit," CapEco writes, "the Conservatives and Brexit Party may form a pact to hoover up the 'Leave' vote; pacts between 'Remain' parties are also possible, although they seem unlikely to be widespread." However, historically, no party has won with such a low vote share before.
  • Pantheon Macroeconomics, which sees the most likely outcome of an election a hung parliament, notes mapping national vote shares to seat predictions is not straightforward, given the structure of the first-past-the-post system in the UK. Winning back Brexit party backers might simply lead to bigger Tory majorities in their strongholds, Pantheon says, perhaps not a slew of new seats, and the Tories look set to lose 13 seats in Scotland.
  • Campaigning may also see some of the 'Johnson effect' pare back (YouGov polls suggest that 17% of voters do not know who they would vote for, leaving Johnson's lead subject to swings in public sentiment). This all comes in the context of an economy facing challenges; analysts have observed that previous governments have not been re-elected when GFK's gauge of consumer confidence has been so low.
  • "Accordingly," Pantheon Macroeconomics argues, "an election likely wouldn't lead to the reinstatement of a credible threat to leave the EU without a deal" and in its view, "the most likely outcome is that parliament remains hung and that Brexit is perpetually delayed. The resulting reduction in no-deal Brexit risk would lift sterling and GDP growth, though not back to pre-referendum levels."

subject: Daily FX Wrap: US-China trade chat, mixed US PMI/ISM, ECB sources and Brexit vote looming
content:
USD

The Dollar has back-pedalled on the back of a significantly weaker than forecast US manufacturing ISM (49.1 vs 51.1 consensus) that overshadowed a rebound in the Markit PMI proxy (to just over 50.0) and knocked the DXY back below 99.000 from 99.378 at best. The weaker Greenback will no doubt please President Trump who has tweeted more critique aimed mainly at the Fed, but the proof of the pudding will come at September’s FOMC. For now, rate expectations have responded with greater chances of a 50 bp ease priced in (around 15-20% from sub-10% pre-ISM).

AUD/JPY/CHF/NZD

The Aussie has extended recovery gains vs its US rival, and the Kiwi to within a whisker of 0.6750 and 1.0700+ at best respectively in wake of the aforementioned contractionary US ISM headline reading, a significantly wider than anticipated Q2 Australian Q2 current account surplus and steady/on hold for now RBA. However, Nzd/Usd still seems vulnerable just over 0.6300 following another decline in NZ GDT and WMP prices. Conversely, the safe-haven Yen, Franc and Gold are now all firmer vs the Buck with Usd/Jpy retreating further from 106.00+ peaks and hefty option expiries between 106.15-20 (1.4 bn) to 105.75, Usd/Chf back down through 0.9900 and Xau/Usd not far from 1550/oz as equities fall and broad sentiment sours. Note, risk appetite had improved somewhat after comments from China’s VP He expressing hope for a compromise to solve issues with the US on trade/tariffs following a meeting with 2 Washington officials, but Trump remained adamant that the US is winning and if the dispute continues through the 2020 elections and he prevails then China faces an even tougher deal.

GBP/EUR/CAD

Sterling and the single currency have both endured wild rides, sometimes in lock-step and also independently as the cross see-sawed on the 0.9100 axis in a circa 100 pip range. The Pound was first to fall asunder after Cable broke below the prior 2019 trough at 1.2015, then 1.2000 and took out more stops residing down at 1.1980 in advance of anti-no deal Brexit rebels launching a bill to block that outcome and force UK PM Johnson to request yet another A 50 extension instead. However, US Dollar’s demise helped Sterling rebound to just over 1.2100 again before a Tory defection left the Government short of a majority and an EU diplomat declared it is now pointless to withdrawal discussions in the circumstances. All eyes now on unfolding developments in Parliament and for detailed analysis with an outlook please refer to the headline feed. Meanwhile, Eur/Usd also posted a fresh ytd low only a few pips away from per-1.0900 support around 1.0923, but bounced firmly as the Greenback recoiled with additional impetus from an ECB sources story suggesting that a package of stimulus next week could comprise a rate cut, tiered depo system and reinforced guidance, even though some GC members favour another round of QE as well. Conversely, the Loonie remains softer vs its US peer after an equally disappointing Canadian manufacturing PMI (Markit version dropped to 49.1 from 50.2) on the eve of the BoC policy meeting (see preview of Wednesday’s event on the headline feed too) with Usd/Cad straddling 1.3350.

EM 

Aside from the Greenback’s retreat, Usd/Zar and Usd/Try were fuelled by macro impulses and bearish chart signals when key/psychological levels were broken after significantly stronger than anticipated SA Q2 GDP and weaker than expected Turkish inflation data. The Rand briefly climbed above 15.1000 and Lira over 5.7400 before some loss of momentum.

subject: ANALYSIS: UK Parliament positioned for a showdown
content:
*LONG STORY SHORT: Parliament is due to return from recess today with a bang as MPs scramble to challenge PM Johnson’s move to prorogue Parliament which would significantly narrow the time for Brexit debates, thus upping the chances of the UK leaving the European Union without a deal.

*THE BILL: The text of the bill which MPs want to use to prevent a no-deal Brexit has been published which, if passed, would mandate PM Johnson to seek a Brexit extension until 31st January 2020 if the PM has not passed a Brexit agreement by 19th October 2019 (the day after the Brexit summit), unless MPs pass a motion to approve a no-deal exit. If the European Council agrees to an extension to the 31 January 2020, then the Prime Minister must immediately accept that extension. If the European Council proposes an extension to a different date then the PM must accept that extension within two days, unless the House of Commons rejects it. MP Hilary Benn stated that the Bill has cross-party support.

*WHAT’S NEXT? (SEE BELOW FOR A SIMPLIFIED FLOWCHART)

  • Today, MPs who oppose a no-deal have lodged an application with House Speaker Bercow regarding time for a Parliamentary debate on the aforementioned Bill. If time is granted, the vote on the Bill could happen later. (See below for today's indicative schedule)
  • If 50% of MPs vote in favour of the Bill, it will be rushed through the House of Lords and written into law ahead of next week’s Parliament suspension. Desks highlight that this is not impossible given that a similar bill (Cooper-Letwin Bill) made it into law within three days back in April.
  • Suggestions have been made that the Government could delay the Bill from passing into law before Parliament is prorogued. Furthermore, PM Johnson could also call for a General Election before Parliament is suspended, which would require the backing of 2/3 of the 650 MPs in order to trigger a poll in Autumn, under the Fixed Term Parliament Act (FTPA). [N.B. PM Johnson can get around the 2/3 majority needed by passing a bill that says "“notwithstanding the FTPA, we will have a general election on XX date”] PM Johnson has warned that if lawmakers vote for another Brexit delay on Tuesday, there will be a vote for a General Election on Wednesday with the view to conduct the vote on 14th October rather than accept another Brexit delay, while reports also suggested that Johnson wants an election before the EU Council meeting scheduled for 17th-18th October.
  • If the vote on the Bill to delay Brexit is defeated, Opposition Leader Corbyn could immediately put forth a motion of no confidence in the Government. This vote could take place on 5th September.
  • If the government losses the no-confidence vote, then MPs could attempt to form a caretaker government with the purpose of delaying Brexit and holding a General Election after. Usually, MPs would have a period of 14 calendar days to form an alternate government, although given the circumstances, MPs may only have four to seven days.
  • If a Government cannot be formed, then an election will be required. It will be up to PM Johnson to set the date, in which he already touted the 14th October.
  • In the event no legislation is passed to delay Brexit and the vote of no-confidence proves unsuccessful, MPs would have another chance to use legislations or a vote of no confidence when the new Parliamentary session starts on October 14th.

*JOHNSON'S RHETORIC: The UK PM has said he is encouraged by progress on Brexit and that chances of a deal are rising, while he added that the EU can see that the UK wants deal and has a vision for future relationship. PM Johnson also reiterated his argument that getting a deal would be made impossible if MPs vote for a Brexit delay (as it would remove the threat of no deal) and that the UK is to leave on 31st October as he will not ask for a delay under any circumstances but believes UK will get a deal at the October EU summit. Furthermore, UK PM Johnson reportedly issued an ultimatum to former Chancellor Hammond and other Tory rebels that they would be expelled from the party if they join forces with Labour leader Corbyn to halt a no-deal Brexit.

*TODAY'S INDICATIVE SCHEDULE:

  • 15:30BST/10:30ET - PM statement on the G7 summit
  • 16:30BST/11:30ET - UK Chancellor Javid to talk about Brexit preparations
  • 18:30BST/13:30ET - House Speaker hears application for SO24 debate, if granted debate can last 3 hours or until 22:00BST/17:00ET (whichever comes first)
  • 21:30BST/16:30ET - Key vote expected

Source: Sky News' Westminster Senior Editor Lucy Plint

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 3rd September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are in negative territory as sentiment is subdued on reports that the US & China are struggling to agree a schedule for September’s talks
  • RBA left rates unchanged at 1.0% and maintained their wait and see approach
  • UK Parliamentarians return to Westminster as Brexit remains the key focus for UK assets
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Construction Spending & ISM Manufacturing PMI, UK Parliament’s return, vote on incoming ECB President Lagarde, Fed’s Rosengren

WEEKEND/HOLIDAY HEADLINE SUMMARY

The new 15% US tariffs on about USD 112bln of Chinese goods went into effect, while China’s Customs Tariff Commission of the State Council also confirmed the first round of tariff increases on USD 75bln of US goods. (Newswires)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Aug) 49.5 vs. Exp. 49.7 (Prev. 49.7); Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Aug) 50.4 vs. Exp. 49.8 (Prev. 49.9); first expansion in 2 months. (Newswires)

ECB’s Rehn (Dove) stated that it is important to maintain strong monetary stimulus and that the situation called for an effective policy package. (Newswires)

ECB’s Holzmann (Hawk) stated he is worried about further additional stimulus to the EU and lowering the deposit rate, while he suggested that if there is an adjustment in rates, it should be a hike not a cut. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded indecisively following a non-existent lead from Wall St due to the Labor Day holiday and as upcoming key risk events, as well as reports US and China are struggling to set a meeting for trade talks this month, added to the non-committal tone. ASX 200 (U/C) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were choppy with upside in Australia limited by mixed data and amid the RBA rate decision where the central bank kept rates unchanged as expected, while advances in Tokyo were restricted by a mixed currency. Hang Seng (-0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) conformed to the indecisive tone after reports noted difficulty in setting up planned US-China trade talks and after MOFCOM lodged a case against the US at the WTO, with PBoC inaction and a net daily liquidity drain of CNY 80bln also contributing to the lacklustre sentiment in China. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued after the pullback in T-notes but then gradually recovered after mixed 10yr JGB auction results.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 80bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0884 vs. Exp. 7.1099 (Prev. 7.0883)

US & China are reportedly struggling to agree on a schedule for this month’s planned trade talks. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam said disruption at the airport has harmed Hong Kong's international image and that the economy is seeing a downturn impacting every industry, while Lam added she believes she can still bring the city out of current trouble and has never contemplated discussing a resignation. There were separate comments from Hong Kong Deputy leader Cheung who does not rule out declaring a state of emergency in response to tens of thousands of high school and university students boycott classes, as well as increasing violence between police and protesters. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

China Hong Kong Affairs Office says Hong Kong situations has seen some positive change, adding that we have come to critical juncture; those who care for HK must fully recognise that there can be no hesitation in stopping violence. (Newswires)

UK/EU – link to UK Parliament analysis piece

Application for an emergency Brexit debate has been submitted as expected, House of Commons speaker will consider it later today. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson said he is encouraged by progress on Brexit and that chances of a deal are rising, while he added that the EU can see UK wants deal and has a vision for future relationship. PM Johnson also reiterated his argument that getting a deal would be made impossible if MPs vote for a Brexit delay and that the UK is to leave on 31st October as he will not ask for a delay under any circumstances but believes UK will get a deal at the October EU summit. In other news, UK PM Johnson said Chancellor Javid will announce a spending round on Wednesday. (Newswires/Sky)

UK PM Johnson warned if lawmakers vote for another Brexit delay on Tuesday, there will be a vote for a General Election on Wednesday with the view to conduct the vote on 14th October rather than accept another Brexit delay, while reports also suggested that Johnson wants an election before the EU Council meeting scheduled for 17th-18th October. (Twitter/ITV/Sun)

The text of the bill which MPs want to use to prevent a no-deal Brexit has been published which, if passed, would mandate PM Johnson to seek a Brexit extension until 31st January 2020 if the PM has not passed a Brexit agreement by 19th October 2019 (the day after the Brexit summit), unless MPs pass a motion to approve a no-deal exit. (Guardian/BBC)

UK opposition Labour party leader Corbyn will not fall for PM Johnson's no-deal snap election trick and will only support a general election if the threat of a no-deal is removed, according to shadow cabinet minister Lloyd. (Huffington Post)

UK BRC Retail Sales YY Aug -0.5% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires) Barclaycard said UK consumer spending increased 1.3% Y/Y. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Cons PMI (Aug) 45.0 vs. Exp. 45.5 (Prev. 45.3)

As a reminder, Italy's 5-Star Movement members will take part in an online vote between 0700-1700BST today on whether the party should form a government with the Democratic Party (PD). (Newswires) Of note, the latest LA7/SWG poll suggests that 51% of 5SM voters support forming a government with the PD party, whilst 69% of PD voters are in favour of forming a government with the 5SM.

EQUITIES

European indices are marginally lower on the day [Eurostoxx 50 -0.4%] following on from a mostly subdued Asia-Pac lead and ahead of US markets’ first chance to react to the implementation of further US/China tariffs. UK’s FTSE 100 (-0.2%) derives some modest support, but remains in negative territory, from the weaker Pound as UK Parliament returns from their summer recess to challenge PM Johnson’s attempt to prorogue Parliament until 14th October. Sectors are mostly in the red, albeit defensive sectors are less dented than cyclicals. Turning to individual movers, easyJet (-3.9%) rests at the foot of the Stoxx 600 index due to a broker downgrade at Kepler Cheuvreux, whilst Iliad (-4.3%) is not far behind on the back of earnings. On the flip side, Renault (+1.2%) and Fiat Chrysler (+2.5%) shares spiked higher amid source reports that Renault and Nissan are seeking ways to end their alliances discord, a resolution may potentially lead to a Fiat Chrysler deal.

Renault (RNO FP) and Nissan (7201 JT) are seeking ways to end their alliances discord, a resolution may potentially lead to a Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) deal., according to sources. (Newswires)

FX

GBP - The Pound has racked up more losses in advance of UK Parliament reconvening after the Summer break and in anticipation of a showdown between anti-no deal politicians across party divides and PM Johnson’s pro-Brexiteers. Like yesterday, stops were triggered in Cable once the previous 1.2015 ytd low was breached and again through the psychological 1.2000 before another round was tripped on a break of 1.1980 that sat just below 1.1986-83 ‘support’ from mid-May 2017. The selling has subsequently abated even though construction PMI missed expectations in line with Monday’s manufacturing headline print, but Sterling remains weak and extending relative declines vs G10 pears with Eur/Gbp firmly above 0.9100 and Gbp/Jpy hovering around 127.00 after an order driven lurch to circa 126.70 at one stage.

AUD/JPY/CHF - In contrast to the underperforming Pound, and despite ongoing strength in the Greenback (ie DXY up to 99.356 at best), the Aussie and Yen are at the top of the major ranks, as Aud/Usd reclaims 0.6700+ status and Usd/Jpy slips back to test underlying bids/support around 106.00. No change in rates or wait-and-see guidance from the RBA overnight has helped the Aussie stabilise amidst the ongoing US-China trade stalemate and further Yuan weakness, while a broader downturn in risk sentiment is keeping the Yen underpinned alongside Gold, but not the Franc uniformly. Indeed, Usd/Chf is still holding above 0.9900, while Eur/Chf creeps deeper below 1.0850, albeit largely due to Euro depreciation on top of no verbal intervention from the SNB, so far.

CAD/NZD/EUR - The Loonie and Kiwi have both lost more ground relative to their US peer (and latter against the aforementioned recovering Aussie as Aud/Nzd eyes 1.0700), with Usd/Cad climbing above 1.3350 ahead of NA Markit manufacturing PMIs, and ISM in the US, while Nzd/Usd has pulled back under 0.6300 into the latest GDT auction and not really gleaning support from NZ Finance Minister Robertson noting some robust domestic data and firm economic fundamentals, as he also stated that the Government is ready to react in the case of a shock. Elsewhere, the single currency continues to decline as noted above, and closer to 1.0923 support ahead of 1.0900, but may find some traction from hefty option expiries close by (2 bn between 1.0945-50).

EM - The Rand and Lira look technically and fundamentally ripe to claw back ground vs the Buck, with Usd/Zar reversing from almost 15.2900 towards 15.1250 and Usd/Try touching 5.7650 compared to 5.8220 at the other extreme in wake of SA GDP and Turkish CPI that confounded forecasts on the upside and downside respectively.

RBA kept the Cash Rate unchanged at 1.00% as expected. RBA stated the outlook for global economy is reasonable and that it is to ease policy if needed to support sustainable growth, while it added rates are to remain low for an extended period. RBA reiterated that it will monitor developments in labour market closely and that signs of a turnaround in housing market but sees inflation likely to be subdued for some time and noted the outlook for consumption remains the main domestic uncertainty.

Australian Current Account Balance (Q2) 5.9B vs. Exp. 1.4B (Prev. -2.9B). (Newswires) Australian Net Exports Contribution (Q2) 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.2%) Australian Retail Sales (Jul) M/M -0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.4%)

FIXED

Gilts continue to lead the way in core debt markets and only ran out of steam when 136.00 seemed to offer too much resistance, with the 10 year debt future subsequently drifting back down towards 135.40 vs 135.90 at best. Similarly, Bunds are pausing for breath after just eclipsing their previous best, at 179.67, and perhaps -75 bp in cash terms proved sticky, while US Treasuries are hovering just shy of overnight session highs awaiting desks to return stateside from the long holiday weekend. Note, however, the curve is flatter/inverted and 10/30 year yields are back below 1.5%/2% respectively ahead of Markit and ISM manufacturing surveys.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are on the backfoot in early EU trade, with prices around 54/bbl and under 58/bbl respectively. Prices may also see divergence as WTI had no settlement yesterday due to the US Labor Day Holiday, which will also see the weekly API and DoE inventory data pushed back by a day. Price action has largely been dictated by sentiment thus far, with ongoing US/China, Brexit and Hong Kong woes weighing on risk appetite. State-side, NHC said a tropical cyclone is expected to form later today over SW Gulf of Mexico, tropical storm warnings have been issued for portions of NE Mexico. The potential tropical cyclone Seven is located about 220 miles East of La Pesca, Mexico, with maximum sustained winds of 35mph. Meanwhile, Hurricane Dorian is reportedly stationary and is expected to drift North/Northwest later, away from the Gulf of Mexico. Elsewhere, gold is relatively flat but off of intra-day lows and in positive territory despite the DXY printing fresh YTD highs as investors increase positions in safe-haven assets. Conversely, the risk aversion has taken a toll on copper prices which currently reside below the 2.50/lb level. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures rose in excess of 4% amid a rosier demand outlook for the base metal as steel mills restock their supplies.

Saudi Arabia removed Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih from his position as Chairman of Saudi Aramco and appointed public investment fund head Yasir Al-Rumayyan as the new Chairman ahead of an IPO. (Newswires)

NHC says a tropical cyclone is expected to form later today over SW Gulf of Mexico, tropical storm warnings have been issued for portions of NE Mexico. (Newswires/NHC)

subject: European Commission Spokesman says the working assumption is that Brexit happens on October 31st, we have progressed on process in Brexit talks, still need concrete proposals to replace backstop
Nomura Quants see ISM, NFP as key determinants of equity sentiment this week
content:
• Nomura underlines the importance of figuring out how fundamental oriented investors, such as global macro hedge funds, will behave as they return after the Labour Day holiday. As the bank has frequently noted, these investors have taken a bullish stance based on strong macro fundamentals of the US economy as of late (moving into equities from bonds). As such a key determinant of sentiment this week is likely to be US macroeconomic data releases, with focus inevitably centred around ISM and NFP data. “If the incoming macroeconomic data proves conspicuously disappointing, and if global macro hedge funds were to respond by exiting enough long positions in equities to pull the S&P 500 down to below 2,860” the bank posits, “algo investors would probably return to a preference for bear trades”.
  • Nomura notes that systematic CTA players have been closing out some of their long 10-year UST future positions. According to their model, Nomura says that CTAs' net buying of TY since 1 August (which makes up roughly 30% of their total net long position) breaks even at a 10-year UST yield of about 1.56%, making this a level to watch. Should yield move above this point, Nomura see the next trigger line in for CTAs at around 1.79%, the break-even line for CTA net buying since June.

content: The 10 year UK benchmark has printed new contract highs after scaling 135.00 again off the open and surpassing Tuesday’s session peak of 135.04, at 135.75, with the equivalent yield down below 0.37% in tandem as the Pound comes under more pronounced pressure in FX markets. Heightened political and related Brexit uncertainty is weighing on Sterling and fuelling the bid in debt/STIR contracts, with BoE rate cut odds slashed in the process as the 3 month strip climbs as much as 5 ticks by June 2021. Ahead, the construction PMI is forecast to inch up, but the bias around consensus looks skewed to the downside after the bad manufacturing miss and at this stage upcoming 2025 issuance is not even prompting caution let along a concession or much cash hedging.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

3rd September 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded indecisively following a non-existent lead from Wall St due to the Labor Day holiday and as upcoming key risk events, as well as reports US and China are struggling to set a meeting for trade talks this month, added to the non-committal tone. subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 3rd September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded indecisively following the US holiday and reports the US and China are struggling to set a meeting for trade talks this month
  • UK PM Johnson warned if lawmakers vote for another Brexit delay on Tuesday, there will be a vote for a General Election on Wednesday
  • RBA kept rates unchanged at the record low of 1.00% and noted the global economy remained reasonable
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Swiss CPI, UK Construction PMI, EZ PPI, US Construction Spending & ISM Manufacturing PMI, UK Parliament’s return, vote on incoming ECB President Lagarde, Fed’s Rosengren, SNB’s Jordan, supply form the UK

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded indecisively following a non-existent lead from Wall St due to the Labor Day holiday and as upcoming key risk events, as well as reports US and China are struggling to set a meeting for trade talks this month, added to the non-committal tone. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were choppy with upside in Australia limited by mixed data and amid the RBA rate decision where the central bank kept rates unchanged as expected, while advances in Tokyo were restricted by a mixed currency. Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) conformed to the indecisive tone after reports noted difficulty in setting up planned US-China trade talks and after MOFCOM lodged a case against the US at the WTO, with PBoC inaction and a net daily liquidity drain of CNY 80bln also contributing to the lacklustre sentiment in China. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued after the pullback in T-notes but then gradually recovered after mixed 10yr JGB auction results.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 80bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0884 vs. Exp. 7.1099 (Prev. 7.0883)

US & China are reportedly struggling to agree on a schedule for this month’s planned trade talks. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam said disruption at the airport has harmed Hong Kong's international image and that the economy is seeing a downturn impacting every industry, while Lam added she believes she can still bring the city out of current trouble and has never contemplated discussing a resignation. There were separate comments from Hong Kong Deputy leader Cheung who does not rule out declaring a state of emergency in response to tens of thousands of high school and university students boycott classes, as well as increasing violence between police and protesters. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said he is encouraged by progress on Brexit and that chances of a deal are rising, while he added that the EU can see UK wants deal and has a vision for future relationship. PM Johnson also reiterated his argument that getting a deal would be made impossible if MPs vote for a Brexit delay and that the UK is to leave on 31st October as he will not ask for a delay under any circumstances but believes UK will get a deal at the October EU summit. In other news, UK PM Johnson said Chancellor Javid will announce a spending round on Wednesday. (Newswires/Sky)

UK PM Johnson warned if lawmakers vote for another Brexit delay on Tuesday, there will be a vote for a General Election on Wednesday with the view to conduct the vote on 14th October rather than accept another Brexit delay, while reports also suggested that Johnson wants an election before the EU Council meeting scheduled for 17th-18th October. (Twitter/ITV/Sun)

The text of the bill which MPs want to use to prevent a no-deal Brexit has been published which, if passed, would mandate PM Johnson to seek a Brexit extension until 31st January 2020 if the PM has not passed a Brexit agreement by 19th October 2019 (the day after the Brexit summit), unless MPs pass a motion to approve a no-deal exit. (Guardian/BBC)

UK opposition Labour party leader Corbyn will not fall for PM Johnson's no-deal snap election trick and will only support a general election if the threat of a no-deal is removed, according to shadow cabinet minister Lloyd. (Huffington Post)

UK BRC Retail Sales YY Aug -0.5% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires) Barclaycard said UK consumer spending increased 1.3% Y/Y. (Newswires)

 

As a reminder, Italy's 5-Star Movement members will take part in an online vote between 0700-1700BST today on whether the party should form a government with the Democratic Party (PD). (Newswires) Of note, the latest LA7/SWG poll suggests that 51% of 5SM voters support forming a government with the PD party, whilst 69% of PD voters are in favour of forming a government with the 5SM.

 

FX

 

DXY was firmer and extended above 99.00 as price action began to pick up following the holiday lull and amid weakness across its major counterparts including EUR/USD which recently gave up the 1.1000 handle on its retreat to fresh multi-year lows. GBP/USD also languished below 1.2050 after the prior day’s losses that were triggered by Brexit uncertainty and election risk with opposition MPs and Tory rebels planning to push through legislation to force a 3-month delay if a deal cannot be reached by 19th of October, although PM Johnson hopes to quell these efforts with the threat of a snap election which could result to a greater majority for the government. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were mixed with the divergence driven by their base currencies, while antipodeans were pressured in which AUD/USD and NZD/USD slipped below 0.6700 and 0.6300 respectively after CNH recently hit fresh record lows and as participants digested mixed data in which Australia posted its first Current Account surplus in over 4 decades and stronger than expected net exports contribution ahead of tomorrow’s GDP, but missed on Retail Sales. Furthermore, AUD/USD was later supported and recovered most its losses after the RBA rate decision in which it kept rates unchanged at the record low 1.00% and noted the global economy remained reasonable, while its statement was mostly a reiteration and did little to support expectations for a cut at the next meeting.

RBA kept the Cash Rate unchanged at 1.00% as expected. RBA stated the outlook for global economy is reasonable and that it is to ease policy if needed to support sustainable growth, while it added rates are to remain low for an extended period. RBA reiterated that it will monitor developments in labour market closely and that signs of a turnaround in housing market but sees inflation likely to be subdued for some time and noted the outlook for consumption remains the main domestic uncertainty.

Australian Current Account Balance (Q2) 5.9B vs. Exp. 1.4B (Prev. -2.9B). (Newswires) Australian Net Exports Contribution (Q2) 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.2%) Australian Retail Sales (Jul) M/M -0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.4%)

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were lacklustre in which WTI crude futures remained subdued below the USD 55.00/bbl level amid the indecisive risk tone and following the US holiday lull, which also means participants will have to wait until Wednesday for the latest API inventory release. Elsewhere, gold prices were subdued as the greenback firmed overnight and copper also mirrored the weakness across the complex amid the ongoing US-China trade uncertainty.

Saudi Arabia removed Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih from his position as Chairman of Saudi Aramco and appointed public investment fund head Yasir Al-Rumayyan as the new Chairman ahead of an IPO. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US will withdraw troops from 5 bases in Afghanistan under a proposed agreement with the Taliban, according to US envoy Khalilzad. (Al Jazeera) 

US

Virginia Governor Northam declared a state of emergency ahead of hurricane Dorian's impact on south-eastern Virginia. (Newswires)

Preview: RBA expected to keep rates at record low 1.00% at announcement due in 15 mins
content:
The RBA is expected to keep rates unchanged at the record low 1.00% in its latest policy meeting today with ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures pricing in 87% expectations for no change in rates and a 13% chance of a 25bps cut, while its implied yield curve points to a 25bps cut at the October meeting and another similar reduction to 0.50% in December.

The wide expectations for the RBA to remain on hold for a consecutive meeting are mainly due to the close proximity since the last policy adjustments in which it delivered back-to-back cuts in June and July. It would therefore be prudent for the central bank to bide its time and gauge the impact on the economy from its past adjustments. Nonetheless, additional policy loosening for the year is seen to remain firmly on the table given the ongoing US-China trade war, global growth slowdown and declining rates across the world's central banks including the Fed which recently cut rates for the first time in a decade and last month's surprise 50bps bonanza by the RBNZ. In addition, the quarterly Statement on Monetary Policy noted the board is prepared to ease policy if needed and are observing the labour market, while it added that it is reasonable to expect an extended period of low rates and included the technical assumption for rates to decline to 0.75% by year-end in its economic forecasts.

Other comments from the central bank point to a lack of urgency to act again so soon as RBA Governor Lowe stated at the recent Semi Annual Testimony that he thought it was appropriate to wait and assess developments after having cut rates in quick succession but added the board is prepared to ease further to meet goals and suggested scenarios where zero rates could be considered such as if all central banks go to zero or if the economy weakens well below expectations. However, Governor Lowe also noted the fiscal option should be on the table if demand weakens and that the economy may have reached a "gentle turning point". Elsewhere, Assistant Governor Kent thinks it is unlikely that very low or negative rates will be needed in Australia but still noted that low interest rates and some unconventional policies are possible, while Deputy Governor Debelle hopes the RBA never have to get down to minimum rate levels seen in other developed countries.

The recent data has been mixed and therefore favours a wait and see approach as Employment Change topped estimates in July at 41.1k vs. Exp. 14.0k (Prev. 0.5k) which was predominantly driven by an increase in Full Time Employment and although the Unemployment Rate remained at 5.2% as expected, this coincided with an increase in the Participation Rate. Furthermore, Building Approvals disappointed at -9.7% vs. Exp. 0.0% (Prev. -1.2%) and there was a surprise contraction in Private Capital Expenditure for Q2 at -0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. -1.7%) although the latest 2019-2020 Private Capex estimate was revised higher to 113.4B (Prev. 99.14B), while the looming Q2 GDP figures for Australia due this Wednesday adds to the case for the RBA to stand pat.

The rate decision is due at 0530BST/2330CDT/1230HKT and aside from the actual rate decision, the focus will also be on the statement as any clues which support market expectations for a rate cut in October will likely pressure AUD, while a lack thereof could trigger some unwinding of the dovish bets for the remainder of the year and underpin the currency.

Recent Comments and Calls

AMP Capital and Barclays both expect the RBA to cut rates in September and November this year.

CBA forecasts the RBA will lower rates by 25bps in November and February to take the Cash Rate Target to 0.50%.
